results.title: A Man of the world: H.H. the Aga Khan
results.creator_credit: Georges Robin, Anthony de Lotbinière and BBC-TV
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Pacemakers”.
The Aga Khan is the creator of one of the world’s most dramatic and imaginative development schemes - a planned riviera along 35 miles of Sardinia’s Costa Smeralda. He is also the spiritual leader of more than 12 million Ismaili-Muslims scattered around the world, and a wealthy Parisian, racehourse owner, and Olympic skier. Shows the Aga Khan in a variety of activities. He comments personally, analysing himself and his different faces with the same detached lucidity he brings to all his undertakings.

results.title: A Man of the wilderness
results.creator_credit: Georges Robin, Anthony de Lotbinière and BBC-TV
results.brief_description: In the southern part of France there is a part which is stark because of the lack of water, and almost impossible to live off. But one man, Phillippe Lamour bought a farm in the area. During the war he cultivated his vines and made a success of it. Other Langadock farmers came to look upon him as a leader. After the end of the war he lobbied government to provide funds for an irrigation project. After 12 years of frustration the project finally started - irrigation enabled farmers to produce extra goods, their standard of living increased by 40%-50%. Lamour’s vision of agriculture, industry and tourism is now being realised.

results.title: A Man and his dog
results.creator_credit: Australian National Film Board and Supreme Sound Studios
results.brief_description: An account of the training of Kelpie dogs in the handling of sheep on an Australian sheep station. Explains the possible origin of the breed; shows the special training a dog receives from the time he is a small pup until he can muster and control a mob of a thousand or more sheep; shows the confidence of the dog and the bond of friendship which springs up between the animals and their masters.

results.title: A Look outside (TEFC)
results.creator_credit: Dave Gibson, Gibson Film Productions and Zero 16 Films
results.brief_description: An optional job experience scheme from 4th form at Nenae College helps students bridge the gap between the classroom and the world outside. Various students are shown gaining experience as a surveyor’s assistant, hairdresser, vet’s assistant and farm worker, working one day a week along side adults in these fields.

results.title: A Look inside
results.creator_credit: Victoria. Dept. of Education and Early Childhood Development
results.brief_description: Shows different aspects of work inside the Australian National Animal Health Laboratory. After a brief introduction to the importance of the livestock industry and the effects of disease, viewers are taken inside the laboratory to see some of the microbiological features.

results.title: A Look at sound
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Life Around Us”.
Very clearly, sometime using graphics, this film explains how sound works, how it is measured and what experiments have been conducted into its nature and effects. Some information about the work of Boyle and Edison is given and the physiology of the ear and nature of hearing are explained.

results.title: A Long shot that paid off: CSIRO's atomic aborption project
results.creator_credit: Nicholas Alexander, S.T. Evans and CSIRO
results.brief_description: The discovery in the early 19th century that chemical elements could be identified by observing their emission spectra lead to the development of accurate methods of chemical analysis based on atomic emission spectra. But it was nearly 100 years before Dr A. Walsh of the CSIRO Division of Chemical Physics started asking questions and became convinced that there would be many fundamental advantages in using spectrochemical methods based on atomic absorption spectra. Despite many technical difficulties and lack of interest overseas, Dr Walsh and his colleagues persisted and finally showed that the technique they had devised, had widespread applications in fields as diverse as medicine, engineering, agriculture and mineral exploration. Cinematography: Peter Bruce

results.title: A Long night with lethal guests
results.creator_credit: Oliver Howes, Geoffrey Barnes and Film Australia
results.brief_description: Deals with malaria in New Guinea and research to find a cure. The film travels with a medical anthropologist to the rain-forest clad Schrader mountains where the Hagahai people live. The Hagahai people are being treated for malaria and other related infections transmitted through contact with the malaria-rife coast due to new road and air links. Researchers are looking at the way immunity to malaria works while treating people like the Hagahai.
